Rodenbach Alexander is een rood-bruin en helder biertje dat bij het uitschenken een normale hoeveelheid beige-kleurig schuim geeft, dit heeft een gelijkmatige structuur en blijft sterk aan het glas kleven. Het slaat wel vlug neer tot een zeer dun gelijkmatig laagje. Toch kan je een middelmatige CO2 verzadiging zien van belletjes met een middelmatige grootte. Het aroma is zurig, mischien zelfs melkzurig. Zoetig ook met een hint naar suiker, fruitig met vooral kers, verder kruidig met een vage hint van amandel en wat hout-toetsen. De smaak is wel zeer zoet en wat zurig, weerom het melkzure, het zoete met suiker en een fruitige tint, zelfs een lichte moutbitterheid en ook fruitigheid van de kersen. In de mond geeft Rodenbach Alexander een volle smaak en heeft hij een volmondig textuur en met een normale prikkeling is dit wel een harmonieus en lekker biertje. De nasmaak vloeit weinig uit, is zoet en wat zurig. Ondanks het tamelijk sterke zoete is deze Rodenbach Alexander toch in balans met het zure, de kersen steken er wel bovenuit maar dit mag geen beletsel zijn om dit lekkere en laag alcoholisch aperitiefbier te degusteren.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2016 Very classic Belgian fruit beer, ¬íoud bruin¬í with cherries, in the same tradition as Liefmans Kriekbier (now called Liefmans Kriek Brut) or Verhaeghe Echt Kriekenbier. I have regretted for many years having had the chance to taste this back in the nineties, but having declined because I was not as experienced in beer tasting as I am now and did not care too much for fruit beers - ah, the callowness of youth! Luckily, Palm (now Bavaria-owned), after having received questions from consumers about this for years, has decided to bring it back to life this year, thirty years after it was first launched in honour of the (literally) blind Alexander Rodenbach, a 19th-century politician and brewer (two things that were often linked to each other in those days), and sixteen years after it was put to retirement. Much to the discontent of Belgian consumers, it was first released on the American market (it says a lot that even the family brewers are aware of the fact that the Americans have become more eager for more characterful craft beers than their local audience, but anyway); again after many reactions from Belgian beer lovers, it was finally decided to launch it onto the Belgian market as well. This rating concerns the 155th bottle in that first launch, a luxury 75 bottle from a cardboard box, corked with muselet and white background colour with a picture of the historical figure after which it was named - one thing it has in common with the original bottles from the eighties and nineties. Opens with quite a lot of pressure and smoke coming out of the bottle neck, but there is no gushing. Medium sized, pale yellowish beige-ish head, moussy and stable, leaving a thin veil of the liquid¬ís surface after a while; warm copper brownish-red robe, beautifully ¬íautumny¬í for this time of year, clear initially, with a lively, lambrusco-like fizz. Aroma does breathe cherry juice and cherry jam, but also an unexpected (and for me undesirable) hint of red candy (¬ípoepegatjes¬í), though this is fortunately largely drenched in caramel, sweet sherry, red wine vinegar, redcurrant, some wet wood, cherry pits, vanilla, passion fruit, ros√© wine, apple peel, honey, ripe gooseberry. The red candy sweetness is present in the onset too, again that reminiscence of ¬íHaribo red licorice wheels¬í or something like that, but much to my relief, it doesn¬ít stick around for too long or dominate the entire palate, as is often the case in more artificial red fruit beers; instead, it quickly makes room for a deeper and more convincing flavor of indeed cherries, but also rhubarb, gooseberry, passion fruit and cranberries, adding a deeper fruit acidity to the whole without losing contact with the sweetness; carbonation is fizzy but in a pleasantly refined way, as in some fine red lambrusco. Mouthfeel is smooth and supple, with a lean caramelly and lightly honeyish malt sweet core, of the ¬ímoelleux¬í kind I think is essential in a Flemish red style beer; meanwhile the drying fruit tartness continues and penetrates the palate in a gently drying way, eventually blending with tannins from wood and cherry pits, providing balance against the malt sweetness and that initial red candy sweet touch. Some earthy, estery yeastiness is left in the back of the mouth after swallowing (especially near the end of the bottle, of course), along with that drying tartness. I can still feel a light stickiness of the red candy and that is basically my only point of criticism here: I do not know exactly how this was made (I only know the recipe of the original version), but I am convinced that this is not just old Rodenbach with sour cherries added: this is very clearly sugared as well, and in that sense offers a look back at the eighties, when this beer was conceived because many consumers - having grown up as a ¬íCoca Cola¬í generation - added grenadine or sugar to their Rodenbach anyway and the brewery wanted to find a way to counter this and already add that flavor to the beer itself. I have managed to find a vintage bottle of 1998 as well and I am extremely curious to find out if this original, historical version too had this added sugariness to it, though after almost twenty years, it will doubtlessly have evolved too much to establish that in an unambiguous way, I suspect. I will add my findings of that vintage bottle here too when I open it but for now: great beer for sure, Rodenbach ¬íoud bruin¬í in all respects, glad it¬ís back - and probably for sale in supermarkets here within a year or so; in my unbiased opinion (unbiased since I never had this Alexander when I was young), however, Charact√®re Rouge tops this in authenticity, finesse and complexity - at least the first batch, because from what I have heard, they appear to use syrup in that one too now that it is made in large quantities (time for a re-rate...).

Bottle, shared by Eric. Red copper with almost no head. So dry with lots of cherries, great balance of tartness with the sweetness at just the right level, oak, some funk, long finish with a moderate carbonation and full body that keeps on giving. Yummy.

From notes. Enjoyed at Abu¬ís place on September 13. 750 mL bottle. The pour is a nice ruby cherry color with a thick cap of light tan head (surprising since the liquid is red) and a light lace as it falls down. The aroma is good. There is a lot of cherry right up front. It does have quite a bit of funk and oak on the nose, but for the most part, it¬ís really good. The flavor is a little better. It¬ís got a tartness to it, and then a sweet cherry, like a pie filling, just coating the mouth and lingering. The oak and funk seem to fade, leaving the beautiful cherry behind. The mouth feel is a little thicker and slightly syrupy with a nice carbonation and a lingeringly sweet and tart cherry. There is a bit of funk on the finish, but it¬ís not terrible.

750 ml bottle shared by DrSilverworm - thanks again, Chris! Pours a lightly cloudy ruby red with a small head that forms a bubbly ring but never amounts to much. There¬ís a big cherry character here, tart and sweet, with mineral notes (especially in the aroma), vanilla, sweet malt undertones, red wine, mild spice, and an acetic twinge. Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and a mouthfeel that¬ís both sweet and sour. Expertly done. More satisfying as it opens. I went back for seconds on this one. So glad I finally got to try it.

slight reddish head. burgundy colour. aroma is candy/poepegaatjes/cherries. taste starts like rodenbach grand cru followed by a rather artificial sour cherry candy taste with a sour-sweet finish. medium body and carbonation. not bad, not great. bottle 75cl / 2016 version

Proefglas van 75cl-fles op degustatie "Bieren en hun awards" in het Hopmuseum te Poperinge. U: Helder rood met dunne gebroken witte schuimkraag met een roze schijn. G: Zoet rood fruit met een licht zurige toets. S: Zoet fruitige aanzet. Hout, bessen en kersen. Een licht zuurtje in de afdronk. Ideaal als aperitief. M: Volmondig, stevige carbonatie.

Draft. Pours hazed orange amber with an off white head. Bretty funk and tart cherry base, some oaky tannins, a bit of sweetness, and a crisp and quenching finish. Bang on balance of sweetness and acidity. Good stuff.

Draft sample during Zwanze 2016. The beer is a clear amber with a beige head of foam. Aroma has berry and woody notes. Some berry notes and sweet notes come through in the taste. More sweet than sour. Medium body and moderate carbonation.

On tap in Louisville (KY)

The hits just kept on coming at Holy Grale. Following the globe east I moved from the UK to Belgium to try a beer I¬íve been wishing to taste for a long time now. Bottles aren¬ít that tough to come by though the price stretches the budget. After having some on draft I may take the plunge.

Aroma / Appearance - Cherry red liquid licorice fills the glass with a warm glow. Velvety cream cheese colored head radiates calm. Tart cherries and malt elevate Rodenbach to a new level that is more mellow than the Grand Cru I remember.

Flavor / Palate - Cherry pie filling, sweet custard, and tart fruits burst onto the scene. The flavor lingers in every corner of the throat for minutes after each sip. A robust full bodied and world class profile shines from the first sip to the end. Once again Holy Grale and Rodenbach both deliver.

Never had the old one to compare to this. Seems to me like a Grams Cru with cherries. Maaaaaybe a touch more complexity but definitely a similar beer. Luckily I really like grand cru. Softly sour with oak and sweet n tart cherries. Quite nice.

10k Rating! Bottle thanks to Texasjeep at my 10k/Rick going away tasting. Pours a cloudy amber with medium off white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is strong oak, cherry skin, funk. Thin body, tart cherry, funky, leather, yogurt, light oak, really enjoyed this. Cheers to everyone that has helped me get to 10k, what a long strange trip this has been!

2016 version. Ruby red with a pale head. Aroma is sour cherries, light funk, hint of other red fruits. Medium bodied, lightly sticky mouthfeel, sweet on the palate with a nice tartness. Taste is cherries, forest berries, cherry yoghurt.

2016 Vintage received in a trade via OKbeerfan. Cheers! Pours a murky amber with maroon and red hues. Small off white head fades to light lace. Aromas of caramel malts light funk, oak, cherries and some bread. Taste is malt forward and a bit heavy on the palate. Cherries are present but don¬ít shine like I hope. 750ml bottle pours a purple color with a bit of head. Wonderfully balanced fruit and sourness. Delicate yet full of flavor.
Pours a cherry red with a reddish wire lacing. The aroma is cherry and berry with a hint of vinegar. The flavor is rather sweet, but finishes tart.

Bottle @ It¬ís raining cats and whales tasting: BB 1991: Served in a taster:

text:
Bottle shared by Todd. Thanks!

A: Dark red in color with a pink head.

N: Intense cherry, grapefruit, lemon rind, currant jam, some funk, a lot of oak, red wine vinegar, leather and tobacco. Even more cherry.

T: Quite tart, sweet - but not sweet-tart. So good.

M: Light body, no alcohol, spritzy carbonation. 

O: The Grand Cru with lots of cherry to boot. Just so good; I wish it had never been retired and wasn¬ít so hard to get.

Pours reddish with an off white head. The songs had cherries, such malt, mild sourness, spices and bugs. Nice. It has a medium crisp body with gentle micro carbonation. The taste has the aroma notes with more spice and cherries. Excellent.

Bottle. 2016. Bronze beer with a dark cream head.Oak and cherry aroma with light sourness. Sweet flavor with cherry, light acetic notes and sourness. Medium bodied. Acetic notes and cherry lingers with oak and sweetness.

Draught at Toronado. Ruby red color, white head. Sour/sweet taste with cherries, tart, toffee, oak, syrup and earthy notes. Sour/sweet finish with cherries, tart, earthy notes, oak, syrup and grass. Excellent sour.

750ml bottle 2016 release, pours dark blood red with light pink head. Nose has sole vinegar, tart cherry, leather, sweet fruit. Taste is crisp, medium tartness, cherry juice, cherey soda, sweet, light vinegar compared to nose, old leather and toasty crust, light oak presence, subtle vanilla. Solid stuff but not really a significant improvement over standard Grand Cru or Caracter Rouge for me personally.
[2016] 750ml bottle. Deep brownish red with a foamy beige head. Flavors are black cherries, balsamic vinegar, vanilla and oak with vinous notes. Medium body, good, oily texture.

I really think people are screwing with this rating or I got a bad pour: Pours dark red with a thin pink head. Aroma of cherries, oak, and sugar. Taste is lots of cherry and a ton of syrupy sweetness, almost making the cherries seem fake. Way too sweet, barely tart at all. It¬ís not very good.

Bottle shared Bottle shared. Clear amber red pour with thick foamy white head. Aroma is really fruity, nice mild acetic notes with pulpy cherry notes. Taste is lightly tart, very fruity, nice cherry juice. Palate is med bodied with good carbonation. Very good.
On draught. Pours a deep pink, almost ruby, with a moderate pink head that persists. Nose is sour cherries and yeast. Taste follows, with noticeable oak characteristics on the finish. Superb.

Gwnaed gan Gwlad Belg yn Brouwerij Rodenbach , Alexander yn cymysgu Fflandrys " foederbier " ( mewn tanciau derw anferth oed) fwydo gyda sur ceirios - a barnwyd ei bod yn rhyfeddol . Rodenbach, Alexander was a blendes Flanders "foederbier" (aged in giant oak tanks) macerated with sour cherries and it was considered extraordinary. Its complex, vinegary tartness was complemented by a malty, red-ale backbone and hints of almond from the cherry pits.

Pours a deep reddish brown on tap with bubbly pink tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of funky barrel sour notes and big dark fruit. Taste follows, acidic and fruity, neither over the top. Bubbly carbonation, amazing to find on tap.
Dark red pour that smells like fresh cherries galore. Not a huge fan of the taste. I love cherries but this tastes like some fake sweetness was added to it.

Most recent batch. Paid $13.99 at local Co-Op. Dark red pour. 3 finger egg white head that faded to a single 
One finger. Smells great. Cereal, cherries, plum and wood. Hmm. This is pretty darn good. Cherry is sweeter than I expected. Juicy, tart. Very sour in the middle. Finish is cherry salad, vinegar, oak, wine and Brett. Nice mouthfeel fro, the bottle conditions. This will age very well I think. It¬ís very sweet now but that¬ís temporary.

2016 batch, on draft in a goblet. Color is a rusty copper. Can¬ít remember the last time a I got a new top 50 tick, let alone on draft. Murky rusty copper. Half a finger of khaki head that reduced to a slight skim with a thicker ring around the edge. Aroma is tart fruit juice. I would say more cranberry then cherry. Taste is juicy, like a alcoholic ocean spray. Touch of balsamic vinegar. Tart acidic cherry and cranberry on the back end. Strong red/brown sour malt base. Pretty good stuff, unbelievable that they were making this stuff so long ago when the sour scene just took off recently. A lot of stuff has caught up and passed it, but it¬ís great to finally taste the godfather of the fruited sour.

1986 vintage: Color: a red-tinged copper. Smell: sourly sweet, pleasing. Taste: One of the best beers I have had. Nice sour cherry that strengthens as it warms. Not astringent. This could be drunk all day on a hot summer day. The new version tastes nothing like the old. The new 2016 is a completely different beer. It doesn¬ít hold up to the old version. I don¬ít know why they are being rated together.

25 cL bottle poured into a snifter. Didn¬ít record the year of the bottle, probably 2000.  Originally reviewed 12/20/2014.

Deep reddish brown. Some large chunks of bubbles. A few wisps on the surface.

Cherries are still quite apparent. Deep caramel. It is a little bit medicinal, but just a little.

Taste is surprisingly good. Bright cherries. Nice tartness. Caramel malt. Clean finish. Lingering cherry flavor.

Low carbonation, if any. Medium body.

Remarkably good, especially for its age.

Reddish pour thin white ring of head ... Aroma of cranberry and sweet cherry pie .... Sweet cherry and tart ..... Taste is of sweet cherry, tart and slightly sour .... Cranberry and sweet cherry all day long ..... Gorgeous brew a bit one dimensional but sweet juicy and tasty stuff ... Finished dry and sour
Best before 1991. Bruin koper helder bier met een kleine witte schuim kraag. Ruikt ranja, alcohol, zoet, zuur. Smaakt zoet en zuur. Ranja, zoet fruit, druiven.

Rhubarb and cherry aroma. Crisp and smooth with a hint of sour. Much better than the normal Rodenbach.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle at the July DC tasting. Poured a very ruby red color with a very light dull off-white pink head. Aroma was boozy apricot, stonefruit. Light woody vinous notes. Light tartness. Very tasty.

750, corked and baled. Thanks for the tip, N! Pours a murky dark crimson with a loose pink fizzy head that fades pretty quickly. Tart nose, showing a nice balance between cranberries and tart cherries up front, then balsamic and raspberry in the background. Creamy medium body with lively carb, almost fizzy at first. Cherries and cranberries, then balsamic and berries on the mid palate. Long tart finish. Lovely.

2016 Bottle shared at Belgian Chimipalooza, thanks! Hazy dark amber with an off white head. Aroma of tart red fruits, light citrus, caramel, malt an overripe fruits. Flavour is moderate sweet and sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. (Rating split back out from original version after being merged then unmerged)Earlier Rating: 6/26/2016 Total Score: 4.21990 vintage bottle at DHVL shared. Pours clear amber with a bubbly ring tan head. Aroma of big sherry notes up front, a touch of cheese, light mould, oxidization, toffee, woody notes and light tart overripe dark fruits. Flavour is over moderate sweet and moderate sour. Big sherry sweet palate developing into a sharp citric touch in the finish. Over medium bodied with near flat carbonation. Very nice and has held up well after all the years.

750ml bottle thanks to ratebeer along with a couple regular bottles. Shared with my taste group. Pours out a hazy amber topped with a nice head. Nose is sweet tart cherries oak barrel a nice wood and some funk. Taste is more of the nice sweet tart cherries a little funky tart note along with the wood.Earlier Rating: 6/17/2016 Total Score: 4Bottle a huge thanks to ditmier for pulling out this gem. Pours out hazy brown with mahogany highlights (ya one of the last pours for me a little sludge) topped with almost no head. Aroma was very nice sweet honey, cherries, dust, vanilla, and caramel. Taste was also very nice the sweetness still holds up. Cherries, vanilla, vinegar, light tart, and ends with light sour fruit notes. Thanks again Eric for sharing this.
Very nice stuff. Cherry and some raspberry. Ruby red pour with good pink head and lacing. Plum and apricot. Great stuff. Tangy sweet finish. Bottle thanks to Joe T.

Bottle at DC beer gathering. Tart cherry pie with vanilla shoved in to a bottle. It¬ís very good. Right amount of tart that starts in nose and follows down the gullet. The sugar level is just slightly off, can¬ít put my finger on it. But would definitely have more
From a bottle at the DC tasting July 10, 2016. Pours a clear deep amber with a thin off white head. Aroma of sour cherries. Flavors of dark fruits and toffee. Slightly sour finish.

Poured into a snifter showing moderately filtered copper and crimson with sparse foam. 

The nose shows pungent, dry, sour notes with hints of vanilla. 

The palate is light bodied and moderately filtered. Flavors of forward vanilla with light tart around the edges without any acidity. Drinks extremely easy. Fruit flavors appear on warming up - showing plums and light raspberries.

750 ml bottle by mail courtesy of joet through intermediaries, thank you all! Clear bright reddish amber color, off white head. Aroma of cherry and light tannins. Taste has sweet cherry, tannins, plums. Less complex than the original, and sweeter.Earlier Rating: 12/21/2008 Total Score: 41983 bottle.  Murky reddish brown, scant white head.  Aroma of sour cherries and plums.  Slightly sweet sour flavor with nuts and dark fruits.  Wood finish.  Nice one.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle. 
Aroma is very fruity and cherry forward, but it also contains some grape and raspberry notes. A bit tannic with some fruit skins. Some light medicinal notes with a bit of a steamed vegetables character. Faint oak. 
Pours a somewhat deep red with some brown hues and a medium sized, thick, slightly pink head that recedes slowly to a thin film that lingers thicker on the edges. No lacing or legs. 
Flavor is moderately sweet with lots of candy-like cherry notes. Light acidity with some medium light cherry skin tannins. Some light grape and raspberry notes. A touch medicinal with a light green vegetation note. Less medicinal and vegetal than in the aroma. Faint oak. 
Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a nice beer but it¬ís too sweet and candy-like for me. Seems to lack complexity and the aroma is a bit off.

I¬íve waited a long time to try this, and it did not let down. Reddish brown colored, moderate to large light tan head, some lace/retention. Aroma is sour cherry, sweet cherry, oak barrel, vinegar, wood. Medium to light body, extremely drinkable, moderate sourness, moderate sweetness, big cherry flavors. The phoenix has indeed risen from the ashes.
Bottle - Vanilla, cherry and light Woody notes. A touch of balsamic. Clear reddish copper with a decent beige head. Sweet, tart and light acidity. Very well balance of sweet and tart.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2016 Bottle - 2016 - pours reddish cherry off white head - nose/taste of cherry, pie crust, light sour cherry and funky old cherry - medium body. 4.2

Earlier Rating: 6/9/2014 Total Score: 4.5 Bottle thanks to Clark. Shared at Monday Night Tasting. Pours reddish brown with white head. Nose/taste of sour raspberry, oak, bright berry, light caramel and smooth vinegar tartness. Medium body. Held up incredibly well. No oxidation.
Reddish mahogany, clear. Deep sour cherry, medicinal. Some light funk. Quite sour, very sweet. Oily, medium body, long finish. Great.

Big cherry, solid wood, balsamic, barrel, funk. Classic. Bright reddish brown pour thin white head. Flavors of nice cherry, funk a little musty barrel notes tasty fruity tangy. Again classic. A little balsamic. Lingering cherry, medium sour. Not some rare American sour so probably not as good. Idiots.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co, and dispensed to a snifters displaying a clear & bright, deep rose color, with a finger¬ís width of off white head foam, and spots of lacing. The nose was tart, yet sweet, cherry, berry, vinous, with a hint of barrel/oak. Medium+ bodied, with lively spritz to the carbonation, the taste was similarly very fruity, tart, with a touch of tannic astringency. Extremely refreshing.

Bottle to snifter. Nose is huge cherry with light vanilla notes, light acetic notes, faintly vinegar. Reddish pour with off white head. Taste is a cherry explosion, light cherry skin, balancing tartness without ever being too puckering. Faint vanilla follows through for a cherries and cream sensation. Tartness dries out the finish. Damn good.

750 ml caged and corked bottle shared with DCLawyer. 2016 vintage. Clear dark ruby amber with beige head. Aromas of fruit jam, berries, oak. Tastes of berries, light tart acidic notes, cherries, oak. Medium body wit a dry finish.

Pours ruby-tinged mahogany into a tumbler. Off-white micro head with excellent retention recedes to coat surface. Dark cherry and vanilla oak aromas. Soft with tart cherry and sharp, dry oak upfront turning to sweet pie crust in the lasting finish.

bottle shared that poured a reddish brown no head to speak of. heavenly bliss in a bottle. aroma of oak and cherry. sweet sweet liquid, lovely cherry ale with Belgian yeast and some mild tartness wrapped around the oak. this is an amazing beer. now its gone.
Draught at Ale Arsenal. Clear rose with minimal off white head. Fantastic sour cherry flavor and aroma. Great beer all around and hope to find this over and over again.

750ml bottle thanks to Jeremy. Bottle share on 6/11/16. Pours out a milky amber, appropriate frothy head. Aroma is mostly cherries,tempered a bit by the oak aging. Cherries follow along in the taste, along with a little tartness, some candy sweetness. Lingers but not too long.

750 ml share by johnnnniee, gracias mucho! Light in color brownish/ red. Aroma of subtle cherry, moldy wood, light acidity. 
I don¬ít really like this style at all but that said this still was pretty drinkable. Not over the top sour but has just a light hint of vinegar and tannic quality that doesn¬ít make me want to drink it. For what it is, it is balanced really nicely. I appreciate it for what it is.

From the corked, caged bottle shared by Johnnnniee! Thank you. The color is reddish-brown with a modest head. Notable cherry, barrel aging, caramel, and Belgian toasted yeast character in the aroma. The body is medium or a bit better. There is a definite tart, sour character in the flavor and the cherry is all part of that. Some beer!

Bottle share, thanks to the Ratebeer crew and BuckeyeBoy. Pours a reddish brown color with creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet, tart, oaky, vinous, and a bit of oak barrel. Sour and sweet fruity flavors with a bit more of the barrel. Sweeter overall, but a nice tart funky bit. Quite a bit different than the bottle we had a few years back.Earlier Rating: 3/6/2010 Total Score: 3.9So this is what Eric means when he says ¬íI¬íve got a small bottle to open to get things going.¬í  Trying to figure out how in the hell Santa lets a clown like me try a super-rarity like this is ludicris...  So, thanks a ton to Ditmier for breaking this out (and thus forcing me to start looking for some charity work to do).  Muddy brown with no real head, the displeasing vinegar aroma abounds.  Oaky and light fruit too, but lots of vinegar.  The taste saves the day.  Smooth and silky with oak, fruits, still plenty sour and tart.  Taste is still sublime after all these years.  What a treat!  Thanks again Eric!

Draft (at Holy Grale, Louisville). Cherry, caramel malt and hay aroma. Bright ruby red with small head. Moderately sweet black cherry, caramel malt, and mildly bitter dry hay flavor. Nice body. Pretty sweet - easy drinking, very pleasant.

Bottle shared by Johnnnnie. Pours a pretty reddish brown with a thin beige head. Aromas of tart cherry and baseball glove. Light sour, but more on the tart side. Wild cherry flavor. Sourness is modest, really not bad. Good amount of oak. Modest body. Thanks for the share John.
Bottle from Bert¬ís. Brilliantly clear deep reddish brown with a smallish bubbly white head. Tart cherry light caramel hints of oak vanilla and light balsamc. Pretty damn tasty!

Bottle from a place in Maine near Casco Bay lines. Garnet red with ring. Woody cherry sweet tart port wine aroma. Sour cherry sweet tart with wood and hay and light cereal nice fairly crisp woody finish with some lingering cherry that stops short of syrupy. Medium light body fine carbo. Totally classic taste well balanced ... but does Rodenbach really need cherries. No, I don¬ít think so.
Pours a clear pinkish red with a white head. Aromas of sweet and tart cherries. Like cherry candy. Taste is well balanced. Goes down smooth. Love it!

Pours a medium rust color with three fingers of fizzy eggshell foam. Nice sweet cherry nose accented by some musty basement funk and old wood. Palate follows with a soft sweet cherry flowing throughout. Nice touch of mysterious old wood, basement must, composted funk that has a focused acidity but doesn¬ít get overly acidic at any point. Nice balance throughout and a very easy drinker. Solid, am looking forward to setting one down for a couple years and see if the sweet/sour ratio dries out a bit.
Pours a reddish brown with no head. Aroma of oak, sour cherries and sweet caramel malt. Taste follows, just what you would expect, cherry bomb rodenbach, absolutely fantastic

Draft to taster at The Pint Room. Looks good; a mostly transparent amberish cherry with off-white head. Smells funky, oak, and mildly lactic with notes of cherries alongside a moderate Flanders backbone. A bit of apple cider vinegar as well. Tastes like it smells, but more cherry-forward, and a bit sweeter. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied with some mild tartness and acidity. Enjoyable.
Red pour. Nose is sweet cherries, vinegar. Taste is sweet cherries, light acidity, a touch of vinegar.

Received 3 complementary 2016 bottles from a good friend of the brewery that wants his name to remain anonymous. Sampled along side vintage Alexander 1986 and 1990.

1986 notes: Pours reddish brown with small white/brown head. Nose/taste of sour cherries , oak, bright berry, light caramel and smooth vinegar tartness. Medium body. Held up incredibly well. Little oxidation. 
Rating: 5.0

1990 notes: Pours reddish brown with little white head. Nose/taste of sour raspberry, oak, bright berry, light caramel and heavier vinegar tartness. Heavy body.Also held up incredibly well. Little oxidation.
Rating: 4.75

2016 notes: Pours deep reddish mahogany with a medium head. Nose/taste of sour cherries, little oak and a medium to heavy tartness. Needs oxidation to compete with the older examples. Overall, a great beer.Earlier Rating: 1/21/2013 Total Score: 5(Bottle 1986 first year) Have had this on a number of occasions. Each time it seems to get even better. Top 10 all time beer for me. Most recently served in a Rodenbach Alexander Glass.Pours a nice garnet color with an off white head. Nose is really, really nice with cherry, sherry, balsamic vinegar, and a bit of oaky earth. Taste is definite sour cherry, acetic acid, balsamic, oak, and some light fruitiness. Mouthfeel is quite creamy with good acidity. I am fortunate to have 24 cases of this beer in my cellar.
Bottle at Bills. The label is a glorified Budweiser offering. Flavor is syrup and cherry extracts, light vinegar. Alright tick but the bottle was harsh
On tap at The Publican. Poured dark ruby brown with off white beige head. Aroma sweet musty cherries. Light carb med bod. Taste pretty sweet cherries light tart funk malty

Draft and bottles. All-around gorgeous. Not nearly as tart as expected, much rounder with a complex sweetness - dried fruit, a balanced oakiness, some drier dessert wine vibes, a little biological-style funk. This should age well but it drinks so easy I might just chug it all now. A joy to sip on.

Bottle via State Line..Light red in color. Poured into a snifter, lots of little bubbles that fade fast. Great nose of some funky sour cherries, cheese, fruit notes. Taste is a well balanced sour. Sour cherries are prominent, oak notes. slight funky cheese. Fruit notes in the after taste. Body is light and easy to drink, good carbonation. Overall: Nice sour beer. Hope this is the right rating, since this one is different alcohol percentage (5.6%)

Dark Woody oaky sour cherry Apple aroma. Flavor is the same. Very complex and balanced. Not too sour and super fruity from the wood. Apple fruity comes through more than other rodenbach. Full flavored, balanced and just great. Sour maybe 4 or 5 of 10. Not super sour but just all around well balanced and awesome. Note: Had at Edmunds Oast, was told this has not been brewed for 16 years.  Assuming this is the 2016 version with that info. 5.6% ABV

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Admittely I never heard of this beer until the thread in forums started and noticed it was luckily on tap near work so dropped in for lunch. Intense ruby red beer like fine jewelry. Nose is cherry and some wood notes. Tastes of cherry, raspberry, balsamic, woody, and fairly tart. Like a fruit lambic. Finishes very bright fruits. Medium bodied and not too sweet, hint of candy sugar finishes it. Could see some age benefiting this one. A very nice experience glad I had opportunity.

(250ml 1998 bottle @ DHVL, Liedekerke, Nov 16 2015, split w/ phyllomedusa) Pours clear deep mahogany copper with a big lasting head of whitish froth lingering with loads of lace. Aroma of raisins, caramel, sweet/tart cherries, dark bread, hard cheese, touch musty. On the palate, sweet burnt sugar, sweet cherry, currants, touch of acid light enough that it could be anything - lacto/pedio or aceto, just balances it out. A hint of cardboard oxidation creeps in the middle. Some grain and light oak, dry hay, soft cheese. A bit of bitterness in the finish, like old hops and baseboard. Medium full body, slick, very soft carbonation. Really lovely stuff despite the age on it, a bit sweet and a bit sour but far from bracing, oxidation kept well in check still. Beautiful take on a fruited oud bruin.

Bottle shared @ De Heeren Van Liederkerke. Vintage 1990. Pours very clear amber with no head at all. Aroma is very up front, vinous, acidic, lemony, sherry, cheese, funky, basement and some vanilla even. Sourness hits you when you take a sip, then fades into maltiness and more acidity. Light to medium bodied. Pretty darn good for a 25 year old beer.

Bottle at Heeren van Liederkercke shared kindly by good company. Clear reddish brown with slight ruby hue, amazing color. Barely any head, just some big bubbles. Sherry, some light cheese on the nose, cognac, dried stone fruits, overripe strawberries, light vanilla oak. Hard to describe, it has lots of vinous and wine-product notes, light oxidized and super complex. Medium sweet and light tartness. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Really good, this has held up amazingly well, even though I¬ím sure 25 years ago this tasted quite differently. Massive beer, just the slight cheese on the nose is a bit off putting.

11.2 oz bottle acquired via trade with ClarkVV. Thanks, Clark! Rating #6000. Pours a healthy deep ruby auburn hue, faint haze but near transparent as a healthy carmelized cherry glow tinges the body and edges. Frothy offwhite head atop stays as a mellow filmy layer, decent ringer atop stays small but laces well enough. Healthy colors are deep alluring, fiery copper, flashes of cherry and ruby cut through and catch the eye. Aromas show distinct sour cherries, jabs of tannic oak, cherry skin and some flashes of red wine. A touch of biscuit, lactic acidity is mellow but appealing. A nice sourness, faint leather, sour chrerries and stone fruit. A bit of balsamic, more red wine and some jabs of vinegar give some life on the nose. A bit of biscuit, faint spice and carmelized malts peek through with some gentle oxidation. Initial is a more mellow body overall, a bit more mellowed out than the nose shows. Some cherry pulp, gentle metallic twang and lactic slash. Touches of red wine, stone fruit and a bit of berry meet some gentle oak. A bit more tannic, a touch toasty and oxidized into the backend. Some wet paper, biscuits with touches of balsamic, leather and tannic cherry backwards. A bit of sweetness, spice and lactic twang as we trail out. Firmer oak, a bit of toast and lingering jab of balsamic and oaky life. While the nose pops here and seems to give some healthy nods to the good old days, the beer itself ends up just a touch faded into the backend. Some decent lactic pop, touches of muted and aging malts. Some healthy barrel and terroir with some nice sour pop and nuance up front. Good cherry, sourness and depth trailing back into some firmer oak, fuzzy lactic twang, touches of leather and earth with lingering pokes of red wine, a biscuity malt presence touches of age. Really, letting this breathe and warm a bit really picks up a lot more red fruit, lush cherries and touches of seedy raspberry. That touch of age on the backend and finish rears it head every now and then, reminding you of what this used to be but still how good it is all things considered. Pretty surprised at it¬ís hold up. That bit of dryness and oaky tannic feel hanging on and slowly letting go as we trail out through the finish. Overall a really great nose and appearance still has flashes of greatness at times through it¬ís flavor profile. A bit muted and faded overall with some elegant struts at times. A decent flow with some oxidation and dry tannic elements favoring the backend and finish. A really good beer that I bet sparkled at one point and still holds up against most sours I¬íve come across, nuanced and delicate punching only when it needs to. An honor to try. Cheers.
Bottle - Pours opaque brown. Cherries, sour, oak, and vinegar in the nose. Nice hints of cherries in the taste with the tartness, dark fruits, and grapes.

Bottle split with Bruce and Colin at De Heeren van Liedekercke - Denderleeuw, Belgium. Vintage 1998 (consumed in March 2013). Pours clear, red-brown with a light, bubbly off-white head. The aroma holds lots of leathery fruits, ripe cherries, very light funk. Medium sweet flavor with juicy cherries, faint earth and very mellow leathery tang. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Moderately sweet on the finish with further juicy, ripe cherries, light dryness, soft funk. Well balanced. Wonderful juicy cherry character with accents of tangy, leathery fruits. Has aged gracefully.

Botella de 33 cl tomada en la antigua internacional en septiembre de 1999. con fecha de cons pref para 12-1999. recuerdos dulces afrutados y ligeramente especiados con un cuerpo medio de 6 vol pero con un sabor bastante intenso. Bastante buena, una gran sorpresa en los inicios del mundo belga. No estar√≠a nada mal poder volver a tomarla.

330ml bottle - 

The beer pours out a beautiful purple/brown bruise like of a color (almost looking like a light grape soda) with basically nearly zero head. Aroma is really something wonderful. Strong notes of wet wood, sweet vermouth/sherry, light barnyard/funk, and something that seemed reminiscent of red wine vinegar?? 

The flavor starts out with a strong cherry/port like sweetness but it quickly balanced by an even tartness, layers of vanilla/oak/earth and caramel chews. It really is complex and far removed (IMO) from what the original beer must have tasted like fresh. Now it¬í oxidation seems to work well with the character of the beer and creates something like a really fine brandy/port/sweet vermouth/Flemish concoction. Yowza!
97¬í bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Dark candi, brune tart fruit, other tart tones. No oxidation on flavor, light sweet and fruit like malt. No balsamic or oxidation, a winner in my book.

Clear brown of color without a head. An aroma of prunes, vanilla, spice, cherries, chocolate, raisins and ryebread. A flavor of black currants, weak sour, oak, dark beeries and dry. Still nice after all these years!

Bottle. It was a belting night, with our kid, Glen and the rest of the Belgian crew, Tom. No idea what the bar was called but what a completely mental place. THE oddest beer drinking experiance in my life and one of the best. No idea how old this beer is as the label is pretty much all perished but it¬ís old. Too complex for me to describe, I just don¬ít know enough to do it justice. It was stunning.

Bottle at home, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clear red beer, small stable off white head.
NOSE: sour, sweet, wood, fresh.
TASTE: sour, fruity, wood, little flat though.
Preserved amazingly! Bottle from around 1989.

Thanks Doug for the bottle. Deep copper, clear, off-white head. Bready/toasty malt, plumbs, dates, dried cherries, light sourness. Flavor: dried cherries, moderately sour, bready/toasty malt, dark bread crusts, cocoa, nutty notes, an earthy, minerally note and a lot of complex fruity notes. Complex, interesting.

Poured from a tiny 25cl. bottle, huge thanks to Doug. The aroma is cherries, slight cocoa. The flavor is cherry, caramel, toffee, slightly woody, brown sugar. The acidity is bright making the cherries pop, tasting almost fresh. Very good.
Bottle thank to Tchrome..Pour is redish with a nice white head..Nose is nice cherry, tartness, musty, dry, fruits..Taste is nice cherry, funk, barnyard, pie filling, fruit jelly..

Bottle shared by Doug, thank man 
Clear copper with a small off-white and some lacing. Aroma of ripe fruit, flavors of tart cherries and syrup  
Very good and tasty

Bottle at De Heeren van Liedekercke. Clear copper liquid with medium light brown head. Aroma of almonds, cherries, light toast, light barnyard, light mineral, red berries and lemons. Very delicate and balanced. Taste is light sweet and light to medium sour with notes of cherries, blackcurrants and lemons. Delicious. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Excellent beer, absolutely worth the hype.

Huge thanks to TChrome for sharing this bottle. Brown-red pour with a small head. Aroma smells a lot like apple cider vinegar, without too much else going on. The flavor is a lot different - in a good way. I get a load of cherry notes, as well as some brown sugar, toffee and vinegar. Thin mouthfeel and low carbonation. Awesome.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2017 First rating: Vintage 1998. 250mL bottle at DHVL, pours a deep dark amber with good clarity and a medium beige head. Aroma is a little dusty, with notes of oak, dark fruits, a touch of vinegar, and some sweetness - highly complex stuff. Flavour is a wonderful balance of sweet and sour - amazingly complex stuff - with notes of sour dark fruits, a little vinegar, some candied sugar, and oak. The layers of depth in this are incredible, with a remarkable balance between the sweet and sour. Very low acidity on the finish, with a perfect marriage of sweet and sour. Wonderful stuff. 9 4 9 5 19 4.6/5 
Second rating: Vintage 2016. On tap at Apex, pours a hazy bright pinkish red with a small white head. Aroma brings out dark fruits, lots of candied sugar, a little vinegar, and a touch of wood. Flavour is along the same lines, with tart red fruits, candied sugar, low-moderate vinegar and a little wood. So much sweeter than the vintage I had a few years ago. Doesn¬ít really seem like the same beer, but always difficult to compare different vintages at different ages. All in all, very nicely done, but nowhere close to the heights of the ¬í98 version. 8 4 8 4 17 4.1/5

Holy Mother of goodness. This is the best smelling beer (or anything for that matter) I¬íve ever encountered. Huge thanks to Enjoyit and Phredrik for sharing a couple of these bad boys. 
Pour slightly hazy chestnut brown with not head. (really? older than twenty years and no head?) Aroma of dates soaked in some sort of delicious alcohol, marzipan, vanilla, prunes, raisins, caramel, rum. Oi boy this is outstanding. The taste is sweet upfront, followed by faint bitterness and ends out with some tiny sour notes. Really is a treat. Medium bodied, with no carbonation.

Bottle shared with Bruce and Leighton at DHVL, 22/03/13. 1998 vintage.
Clear chestnut brown with crimson hues, thin off white head that soon clears edgeward.
Nose is rich vinous berry fruits, light nutty tones, brown sugars, woody, tarte fruit.
Taste comprises dark cherries, caramel, sweet caramelised sugars, tarte and slightly soured berry fruits.
Fuller end of medium bodied, smooth as, fine carbonation.
Great stuff!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

shared with 77ships 
BBE 18/5/2000 , belgium standards are 2 years, so almost 15 years vintage i guess ! 
pours clear, red, very small white foam. smells rodenbach-ish, still got carbo, sourness, much cherries ( still! ) sweet, old but not that extremely old in the taste. dry, sugaryu, VERY nice. make this again dudes, seriously !

1999 vintage bottle in Brugge. A red/brown coloured pour with a very small off white head on top. Sour, berry fruit aroma. Tastes sour, raspberries, cherries, tart. An interesting experience trying this, not really my thing though.

Clear reddish brown colour, small white head. Light sour aroma, cherries, caramel, yoghurt and raisins. Quite sour flavour, still a slight sweet touch, light cherry syrup. Sweet finish, raisins, malts and old fruit.
Very nice! Long time want, and it isn¬ít disappointing! Couldn¬ít be happier!
(From 25cL bottle @ The Vintage Tasting during Brugs Bier Festival. 1999 vintage. Courtesy of Jay. Thanks for sharing!!)

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2017 [22.01.2013]Procured @ DHL. Splitsies with Kraddel / Dylan. 25 cl. bottle with BBF 18/05/2000 so presumably 1998 Vintage. Shares some similarities with Vin de Cereal but that one is a bit better. Pours a reddish, raspberry copper, only some brief bublles for a head. Smell is aged Rodenbach, some of their foederbier, quite heavy vinegar, sharp very sour cherry & cherry pits. Taste is bit oxidation, was this sweetened when fresh because I get some similarities here with aged sweetened sours, vinegar, very sour berries & cherries, tad musty, cellar, cobwebs,lingering vinegar in the back, bit affected by age, light bitter cherry pits, touch barrel / foeder, sour base foederbier but ligher, tad wattery. Bit affected by age, thinned out slightly & close to flat. Good but not the best by them nor topping Vin de Cereal. Originally meant as #1800 tick, now I have done all of Rodenbach, wow, whalez bro! // wow at the dude below me who claims to have 24 cases of this one in his basement from 1986 // crazy [750 ml. bottle split by two @ Boxing Day Tasting]New 2016 Version. Far too many people are comparing this batch to how the original run tastes now. Seems silly & unfair. Original Alexander was very sweet by all accounts & those bottles are 20+ years old now. This one pours deep ruby red with an off-pinkish head. Nose is very sweet cocktail cherry & sweet cherry syrup sugar, Maraschino Cherries, sugar, some pleasant artificial cherry. Taste is of sweet cherry candy, lemonade, sugar, Maraschino Cherries, very sweet in a good candy fashion, sugar, excellent for a sweet cherry beer, sugar,... Needed to get a bit into it, I deem it very good for what it is, just don¬ít expect a cherry sour. 4.4/5. [4.5/5 is for vintage bottle from the original batch].

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2016 Original batch tasted in 2013 - 25cl bottle pours a spritzy looking cherry red with zero head.  Nose of apple, celery, bright cherry, cranberry, a little malt, some light vinegar.  Flavor is lightly tart, grassy, cherries, celery, some passion fruit.  Tart, prickly finish.  Very nice.******* 2016 vintage sampled in July 2016, pours a hazy, neon pink/purple with some rose colored head.  Nose has cherry candies, raisins, malt, a little fortified wine.  Flavor is sweet with cherry candy, raisin, a little cherry wine, mild berry too.  Light acid and a little sweetness on the end.

250mL thanks to Mac! Pours a clear deep reddish brown, thin tan bubbles, still carbonated! Thin, layer of persistent foam with spots of lace. Nose is fresh cherry, oak, chocolate, no oxidation, some savory soy/miso, brown sugar. Taste is sweet cherry up front, clean with lactic acid, sugar cube. Palate is spicy, lemon, chocolate, long lactic finish with spice. Warming alcohol. Very clean and enjoyable despite its age. A real treat!

1st bottle is unknown vintage, 33 cl bottle, courtesy of Enjoyit. Pours chestnut with no head. Very good looking. Aroma is far out. Prunes all over the place, vanilla, old dark cherries, delicate spiciness. I can tell that this is old, even older than me. Fuck. Me. Tastes a lot like black currants, a bit of acetic sourness, keeps the delicate balance between sweet and sour. Classic Rodenbach. Magnificent. 10-4-8-3-17
  Next bottle is best by 14/3-1994. More of an amber colour, this is lighter in colour, and probably younger than the one we just had. Aroma is brighter - not at all as dense in the vanilla. More spicy - more fresh - some raspberry, acetic aroma, raisins, cherries. Taste is very balanced between the sweet and sour once more. Notes of cherries, raspberries, a small iron note, slight chocolate, oak, caramel. Tastes better than the other one, by a nose. This one even has a bit of carbonation. 9-4-9-4-19   All in all it is a great honor to taste two vintages of this magnificent beer. I believe that only a hand full of beers in the world will keep up as well as this has. Thanks to √òlkonsortiet for sharing this great experience.

Pours elegantly clear and dark - like cognac. The nose is stupid good. Sorry about that, but this is In a league of its own. We have prunes galore with vanilla, chocolate (Dark and milk) raisins, krohn 1966.. Okay now.. Thats enough. The ballance is of course is not on point but it doesn¬ít matter. The taste coresponds with the nose but the nose is 60% of the experience. Seriously good.

Bottle thanks to enjoyit. Clear, no head. True amber coloured. Slightly oxidized, however prunes, dark raisins and cherry notes dominate the aroma.The taste is sweet and flat. The flavour has quite a lot blackcurrant compared to the flavour.

Bottle at √òlKonsortiet julefrokost. No carbonation. Aroma is all dark fruits, prunes, dades, fantasitic! Blueberry taste, surprisingly fresh. Very good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour out of 250 mL bottle, big thanks to Aaron for this brew, celebrating my wedding.  Dark cherry red pour with thin to no white head, but to be expected.  Aroma brought notes ofslight oxidation but works very well, some of the caramel, toffee notes go into a sherry note, nice cherry, bread, some hints of sour fruits, lemon, nice hint of acetic vinegar leads into a nice lactic note, slightly funky adding to the complexity.  Taste is a wonderful mix of sour cherry, both in lactic notes, nice sherry mixing into the caramel, toffee, slight biscuit, touch of earth, nice dark fruits, finishing slightly tart, slightly sweet, perfectly balanced.

15/X/2012 - 25cl bottle from De Heeren van Liedekercke (Denderleeuw) @ home - BB: 18/V/2000 (2012-1138) 
Clear reddish to dark amber coloured beer, bit aery off-white head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: very fruity start, earthy, tobacco, some acidity, cherry is clearly present, sour, lemony. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: very fruity start, cherry, some cherry candy, sweet but with a sour touch, pretty lemony. Aftertaste: sour, little bitter, earthy, almost vinous, fruitiness, cherry pits, dry tart ending, bit lemony.

bottle shared by david. huge thanks! pshttt... really!? almost clear - huge yeast amount bottom of bottle, light reddish, pink tint, with a small off-white head. tons of raspberries and dusty yeast notes, light chocolate, vinous, lightly oaked, spiced fruitcake. light soft tartness. soft carbonation, light body - very oily, very nice lightly sweet and acidic finish.

Bottle (Wrapped in paper) [Best Before 1996] Thx David.
Pours mahogany with almost no head, some lacing. Aroma is of red fruits, malt, "sourness". Good, fine aroma, but somewhat faint. Taste is of fruits, sweetness, faint sourness. Very mellow. It doesnt seem to have been too spoiled by aging, but I would be very surprised if that beer was meant to taste like that. All is fading away. Overall: Sligth to no oxidation. Easily drinkable. Pretty good, but clearly, and without a doubt in my mind, over the hill. Glad I had a chance to taste it.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2016 Rating # 500. Small pour from a bottle (best before 1996) generously shared by David M., huge thanks  for giving me the opportunity to try this one! Clear reddish brown with a small lacing. About 20 years old and still well carbonated. Intense raspberries aroma with other red fruits, some sweetness and slight sourness. Not overly complex but perfectly balanced. Taste is sweet with red fruits and slight sourness (far less than what I expected though). The red fruits of the aroma and of the taste are completely different (same fruits - mostly raspberries and cherry - but different effect ), the aroma is more like fresh fruits (even after 20 years) and the flavor is more syrupy. Mouthfeel is syrupy. Almost no sign of oxidation. I don¬ít think the beer could benefit from more aging, it may be a little on the decline, but it¬ís still a wonder. Superb balance and nice complexity. Merci David! 8-3-9-4-18

Bottle (750 ml), 2016 version. Shared at tasting, thanks to Dan! Clear orangey-amber with a small white head leaving little lacing. Aroma is super cherry forward - borderline artificial - with nice raspberries presence, a bit of oak, a tiny  bit of ketchup. Taste is not too sour, cherries/raspberries, mild oaky presence, herbal presence and medicinal notes. Medium body. Moderate to medium carbonation. Fruity finish. Soft, balanced and nicely fruity. Tasty.

This gem was generously shared by David M., thanks a lot man! Best before end of December 1996, I was a little worried that this one wouldn¬ít drink anymore. Boy I was wrong! Smell was amazing with red fruits and some sweetness. Taste is more of the same with a good sour but not a bracing one like someone would expect. This 33cl bottle was shared 8 ways but I believe if we had 8 bottles it wouldn¬ít have been enough. It was really THAT amazing! 

PS. We had this back-to-back with the Classic and Grand Cru and this one really stood out!

Bottle @ DHVL. Pours deep reddish brown with a small head. The nose is deep, meaty blackberry and raspberry fruit salad. Jam, hints of yeasty marmite spread. Umami, some ketchup. Lightly salty. Big, complex aromas. The taste is mellow strawberry and raspberry jam. Meaty and vibrant. Full flavors, mild funk and some acidity. Hints of tart balsamic vinegar on the long finish. The is so drinkable, refreshing. Lovely, lively flavors, soft approachable body. I wish I had a case of this! Overall, fantastic. Well worth the wait.

Bottle at BCTC generously shared by Slander.  Pours a caramel color without much of a head.  Smells initially of caramel fruit rollups.  Medium bodied, sweet clean caramel notes come through right away.  Big caramel, toast, sweetness, raisins and more caramel.  Toast, sweet acid, long sweet fruit, toast.  Some faint acetic acid on the finish.  Chewy malt and delicious caramel.  Definitely has a good amount of age on it, and I was never lucky enough to have it when it was fresh so I can¬ít really compare, but currently tastes rather wonderful.  Sort of like a sweet little oxidized dessert in a glass.

Shared by Thorpe429. Thanks a lot Mike! A top want of mine.

The beer is chestnut brown with a touch of crimson, sporting a thin beige collar that leaves some random lacing on the tulip.

The aroma offers a healthy dose of cherries, cherry juice, a bit of oak. Definitely smells like a Rodenbach.

The flavor is a lovely mix of sweet and tart, with cherries shining through beautifully. Age has served this beer well. Mild on the palate and silky smooth. Like drinking fresh cherry juice. It¬ís hard to believe the beer is as old as it is, as it tastes fresh and fruit forward.

Light in body with moderately lo carbonation.

Overall, a delicious treat. I¬ím so grateful for the opportunity to try this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-05-2012

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 Bottle @ De Heeren van Liedekercke. Vintage 1998. Clear reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, port and oxidated. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. Went really well with my stoofvlees. I kept a little in the glass for most of the evening just to have a smell once in a while :o) 20072012 --- Had the 2016 version twice on tap, and it¬ís really nice as well. Much more aggressive and fruity compared to the 1998 version.

25cl bottle poured into namesake snifter. Vintage: 1998. Enjoyed at DHvL in early June 2012. Medium burgundy. Single (khakis) fingernail head on gentle pour. Smell is mix of dark cherry, tannins, and oak. Not much else here, but very deep. Nose is quite inviting. WOW - this beer tastes absolutely beautiful! Combination of cherry and oak. Touch of apple with hidden notes of faint vanilla too. Balance of sweet and sour is well executed and this beer is holding up quite well for being well older than a decade. Soft, smooth, and refreshing. Superb! A thoroughly enjoyable beer! Very well-rounded and has withstood the age of time. A beautiful beer that I would highly recommend to anyone. Simply amazing! Wish I could drink this more often.

250 mL Bottle @ De Heeren van Liedekercke. Pours a deep maroon/brown appearance with a tan, bubbly head. Rich, dark black cherry, fairly acetic tartness, delicious oaky, raspberry aroma. Very rich black cherry, deliciously tart, rich wild cherry, light vanilla, light tannin, oaky flavor. There¬ís a delicious and rich cherry tartness that is complemented very well by moderate tartness. 1998 vintage.

Murky red with a tiny dusty grey foam on top. Suprisingly fresh and fruity aroma with prominent cherry notes. Some tones of cellar time of course but not nearly as much as expected in the aroma. Flavor however reveals more dusty notes with less fresh fruityness, still oak mixes with cherry leading to a long balanced finish with sweet and sour goodness typical of any aged Rodenbach. Light ultra slick body makes for an easy yet complex drinking experience.

Pours a dark caramel color with no head.  Aroma is red wine and maraschino cherries.  Taste is sweet with caramel, cherries and some tartness. Medium bodied and sticky.  Really horid smelling early, but it opened up pretty nicel.  Past its prime for sure.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2016 Last one i had was in 1998 i think.  For traders: i¬¥m really interested in this one. Berries aromas, pours bright red colour, with a thin reddish head. Light body, high carbonation tastes more sweet than acid. Good astrigent finish.

75 cl bottle, 2016 edition.
A bit liveless, unidimensional, straight-forward. Maybe some more ageing...

Bottle (late 90s): Aroma was rich with a wine like bokay; ale poured a rich red color with a mild head. The ale had a sour overtone reminiscent of the Grand Cru, but lightened with cherry essence. Overall, the ale was full bodied, with average carbonation, and a magnificant bitter finish.

Pours a cloudy dark amber color with a small off-white head.  Much sweeter than I had expected.  Lots of caramel and maple syrup.  Heavy on the cherries, a bit of Maraschino cherry note to them.  Oak and oxidation are also well represented.  A moderate tartness, both lactic and acetic, with an almost cherry candy (Lifesavers) flavor.  Fairly substantial caramel and maple sweetness on the palate as well.  Nice, especially considering the beer is 16 years old.

Bottle at De Heeren van Liedekercke, March 2012. Vintage 1998.

Dark reddish/amber with a small head. The aroma was fantastic! Vinous with cherries, dessert wine, dust and some notes of earth. Balanced and quite complex. Mmmmmmm! The taste was also very, very good. Vinous and rather sweet. A pleasant tartness and a lot of cherries. What a creation! Such a pity that the beer is not made anymore. I am in love with Alexander!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2017 1989 Bottle at Brasserie 4:20, come via DHVL, so I gathered. Thanks to Alex for serving this up! Lovely red with no lace or bubbles of any kind. Aroma of cherry, vinegar, yogurt. Clear and crisp. Very acetic flavor, but not overboard. Lots of cherry and vanilla yogurt. Very light oxidation is almost unbelievable for a beer this old. Perfectly aged. Wonderful. This is one beer I did not want to end!

2016 version: 8/4/7/4/15=3.8. Very fruity and also very, very sweet. Jammy cherries, just a bit of vinegar and yogurt, vanilla. Tasty fruit but extremely unchallenging and lacking the lovely sour character of even the Grand Cru. Tastes like they used the regular young Rodenbach. Super disappointing and I can¬ít believe the high scores it is getting.

Huge thanks to daknole as usual. Pour is amber with a khaki head. Aroma shows plenty of berry sweetness, slight oxidation, oak, and a slight medicinal note that blows off after airing for a while. Flavor shows
caramel, cherry balsamic, plum, and strawberry. Overall body is moderate, sweet, and finishes with light acidity.

1998 bottle served in its corresponding glass at DHVL for my Pre-Wedding Celebration. It pours deep red, with a thick, fluffy white head. The nose is jammy fruit, juicy cherry, blackcurrant and some wood. The taste is just so well balanced - tart cherry, jam, strawberry, blackcurrant, wood, vinous notes and a touch of vinegar, with a smooth, slightly tart finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and just the right level of tartness. Very well balanced and straight-up delicious. If this was readily available I could easily drink plenty at a single sitting.

(Bottle) Pours copper amber. The aroma is balanced, complex and mature with tones of red and yellow apples, cherries, dessert wine, honey, old newspapers, dusty attic and raspberry vinegar alongside a light earthy touch. The flavour is light sweet and medium acidic with no bitterness. Vinous and mature. The mouthfeel is tart and bright with a light carbonation. Medium bodied. Fantastic!

Bottle shared by my Director at work on a Friday afternoon, awesome to have a boss that makes a shit ton of money that¬ís into beer.  Pours a murky reddish amber with a thick head, the aroma sucks you in right away, nice tartness from the cherries with a hint of wood as well, the flavor has a good amount of vinegar notes mixed in with the tartness of the cherries and a finish with chocolate, very smooth and enjoyable.  Awesome stuff.

Originally rated August 2006. Had this one at Vineyards, back in the day. Was one of the best tasting beer I had tried at the time. Came in a bottle wrapped up. If they had not discontinued it, I would buy shitloads of this stuff. Had good cherry presence. Goodbye Alexander, now we we have his brother... the Grand Cru.

Thanks to jrallen34 on BA for this excellent tick.  Somewhat hazy reddish brown in color with a small off-white head.  The aroma is nice and fruity, with cherry and raspberry notes and a bit of vinegar.  The flavor is extremely fruity with cherry, vinous notes, vinegar, and other berries.  Somewhat sweet and only mildly tart.  Medium-bodied with average carbonation and only mild acidity.  This tick was much appreciated and the beer was tasty.  I approve.

(33cl bottle thanks to bu11zeye) clear rich amber/orange with a ring of bubbles. Nose of maple syrup, caramel, oak, brown sugar, a bit of moss, no real oxidation to speak of either. Impressive! Taste of black cherries, bit of moss and vinegar, sweet/tart brown sugar, not super complex but very easy to drink and solid. Smooth finish with a tart/sweet linger.

Bottle acquired in a trade with GG (thanks!) a while back enjoyed out of my Rodenbach Alexander snifter.  Pour is deep brownish purple with pretty much no head.  Looks to be still at this point.  Aroma is deep and earthy with notes of tart fruity sweetness and a deeper layer of rich candy sugar and caramel malt.  Flavor is different than expected and really very intriguing.  Not as tart as expected and not quite still- notes of carbonation do tingle on tongue as i sip the beer. Loads of deep earthy rich cereal malt and a light cherry sweetness are first to hit.  Faint hints of sourness do exist, but they are in the periphery.  Also a light prune note with hints of malt vinegar without the sharp acidity. There are also light notes of wood and a faint hint of oxidation present.  Really glad to have had the opportunity to try this one with my wife.  Very interesting beer to be sure.

Cannot remember where or how I had this right now, but it¬ís written down, so yah!  I remember it basically tasting like a more oaky version of Rodenbach itself, with heavier compliments to the sour side.  Was STOKED when I tried it, and am thankful for whoever brought it out to whatever tasting.  YUM!!!

Rich dark red-brown, thin cream ring, light lacing. Heavy synthetic cherry aroma hits nose first, but it draws out malt rather well. Sweet flavor, heavy malt obscures any acid, cherries strong, light tea and paper, thin chocolate, bit of sugars. The dichotomy works well here, but that¬ís all there is, and the thin body continues to harp on the sweetness through the end until that is disappointingly all that¬ís left.

Multiple bottles over the past 12 or so years. Clear dark amber color with no head. Sweet tart cherry juice, wet wood, sherry aromas. medium body with soft co2. Sweet tart cherry, brown sugar, wood,  oxidized caramel flavors--excellent every time i try this one.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Finally cracked this bottle that I received in a trade with thewolf well over a year ago. Thanks again! It pours reddish gold with nothing but a few spare bubbles. Very clear and bright looking. The aroma hits you first with notes of vinegar followed by a lovely combination of sweet cherry cough syrup, vanilla, and slight cocoa. The flavor is unlike any other sour that I¬íve had. Perfectly balanced between sweet and sour, the cherry flavors really come forward with noticeable hints of vanilla and some richness that I can only describe as distantly "chocolaty". The body is very smooth and rich which belies the 6% ABV. It¬ís really amazing how well the sourness has held up over time, although I¬ím not sure how old the bottle is. Not funky at all, just pure liquid gold with great balance of flavors. I¬ím sad that I¬íll probably never get to try this one again!

2 bottles consumed for our bachelor party whale tasting. My bottle was imported and Sean¬ís was straight from Belgium. No year listed on either, but they were clearly different. I am reviewing my bottle as I favored it. Sean¬ís bottle had a slightly better nose but my bottle was more balanced in taste...A dark brown with amber accents, semi clear. The head is light tan, light, looks oily, like an spoil on the surface of the beer...A strong aroma with a nice super strong cherry base, malty vinegar comes through but a little lighter than I was hoping. The cherries have held up great, strong, complex, full of depth...The taste is a great balance, a continuation of the sweet and flavorful cherries with a great vinegar tartness, almost 50/50 split. Take a Rodenbach Grand Cru, add cherries, age it and you have this wonderful beer.

A rare treat I would recommend anyone trying who can get ahold of. No clue why they stopped making this.

Bottle from ¬í98 consumed at DHvL. Brilliant brown/red. Decent white head. Little to no lacing. Smells of sour cherries and dried fruits. Sweet tart crisp fruity taste. A little tannin aftertaste, like iced tea. Definitely a fine beer. Wish I had cases of this stuff. I could drink this one every day.

Huge, huge thanks to Azurelimits for opening this up at his birthday bash a few months back.

Pours a nice garnet color with an off white head. Nose is really, really nice with cherry, sherry, balsamic vinegar, and a bit of oaky earth. Taste is definite sour cherry, acetic acid, balsamic, oak, and some light fruitiness. Mouthfeel is quite creamy with good acidity. Drinks quite well.
